answer_html: So the horizontal asymptotes at positive and negative infinity are both y = 2.
answer_latex:
So the horizontal asymptotes at positive and negative infinity are both
\emph{y = 2}.
hints_html: We find horizontal asymptotes by taking limits of the function at positive and negative infinity.
hints_latex:
We find horizontal asymptotes by taking limits of the function at
positive and negative infinity.
hints_raw: We find horizontal asymptotes by taking limits of the function at positive and negative infinity.
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
We take limits of the function at positive and negative infinity.

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\ &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} \\ &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\ &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\ &= 2 \end{aligned}\]

So the horizontal asymptotes at positive and negative infinity are both y = 2.
sols_latex:
We take limits of the function at positive and negative infinity.

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\
&= 2 
\end{align*}

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\
&= 2 
\end{align*}

So the horizontal asymptotes at positive and negative infinity are both
\emph{y = 2}.

 &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\
&= 2 \end{align}</math>


: <math>\begin{align}
 \lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2x^2}{x^2 - 1}\frac{1/x^2}{1/x^2} \\
 &= \lim_{x \to -\infty} \frac{2}{1 - 1/x^2} \\
&= 2 \end{align}</math>

So the horizontal asymptotes at positive and negative infinity are both ''y = 2''.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{2x^2}{x^2-1}\end{aligned}\]

(c) Find the horizontal asymptotes of \(f\).
